Contractors:
WTG has an electronic program for contractors that includes their safety records.  A review of the contractor's safety record both prior to selection and during their time of employment is being developed.

Training:
With the enhancement of various PSM elements such as PSI, PHAs, operating procedures, PSSR, MI, MOC, incident investigations, etc., additional training (computer and classroom based) will be established to ensure all Benedum employees are knowledgeable in these processes.

Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:
The process at Benedum has hazards that must be managed for continued safe operation.  Following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.

Universal Prevention Activities
The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the RMP-covered process at Benedum.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features:

The Benedum Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help:
I.	contain/control a release
II.	quickly detect a release; and
III.	reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.

Release Detection
I.	Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms located throughout the process along with automatic shutoff of natural gas compressors
II.	Fire eyes located within each compressor building and connected to the automatic shutoff of the natural gas compressors 
III.	Remote emergency shutdown for all inlet gas pipeline valves
IV.	Hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms located in designated process areas
V.	Routine operator rounds/equipment inspections
VI.	Operators are on-site continually (8,760 hours per year)

n HMO Heater rupture that resulted in a fire.  The rupture was the result of the presence of air and condensate in the heater thereby creating an explosive atmosphere.  The fire was quickly extinguished by plant personnel and the only impact from this incident was significant on-site property damage.  Details of this incident are included in Section 6 of the RMP.  Due to the enhanced PSM/RMP program at WTG, this incident was identified as subject to RMP reporting requirements; therefore, it is being reported at this time as part of the RMP renewal.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
WTG Benedum will continue to improve its safety and environmental performance through emphasis on the continued development of it's PSM Program.  Improvement plans include process engineering support to update critical PSI data for the site; operating procedures written for each mode of operation and to include consequences of deviations; an operator certification training program established from the new operating procedures, new process hazard analysis (PHA) procedure and team structure ensuring employee involvement, new MI program incorporating the implementation of all new inspection procedures and frequencies all to be carefully reviewed, and recommendations for improvement generated using WTG's new compliance audit process.

Accidental Release Prevention Policy:
Protecting and responsibly managing natural resources demonstrates stewardship and is critical to the quality of life in the communities we serve, to the environment, and to WTG South Permian Midstream LLC (WTG's) long-term business success.  Promoting the health and safety of co-workers, contractors, customers, and communities is the responsibility of all WTG employees.  WTG will meet all applicable laws, rules and regulations.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:
Benedum Gas Plant (Benedum), located in Midkiff, Upton County, Texas, is a natural gas liquids recovery plant that produces pipeline specification natural gas and natural gas liquids (NGL, also known as Y-grade) from low pressure field gas and high pressure natural gas collected throughout the upstream gathering system.  Benedum treats and processes flammable gas and liquid mixtures in an amount greater than the threshold quantify containing any of the following RMP-regulated constituents:
¿	Methane
¿	Ethane
¿	Propane
¿	Isobutane
¿	Butane
¿	Isopentane
¿	Pentane

The only RMP-regulated toxic constituent present at Benedum, which is part of the amine treating process, is hydrogen sulfide; however, quantities at this facility are well below the threshold quantity. 

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
WTG is committed to ensuring a safe work environment for all its employees, contractors, and vendors.  The Benedum Gas Plant has a detailed Emergency Action Plan and has coordinated with the community's local responders through mock emergency simulations in order to introduce the local responders to the facility and its personnel.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program:
The Benedum process is covered by OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of highly hazardous chemicals (PSM) regulation.  WTG considers the systems developed for compliance with PSM to be the basis for good safety and business p

ractices.  In this effort, WTG identifies opportunities to continuously improve initiatives for each PSM element.  The PSM elements are implemented to satisfy the PSM/RMP requirements since the Benedum Gas Plant qualifies as a program level 3 RMP process.

Employee Participation:
Employee participation is the foundation block to an evergreen and integrated PSM program.  Thus, the current PSM improvement initiative is heavily focused on this key element as employees are becoming more actively involved in the implementation of each element of PSM.

Process Safety Information:
Comprehensive reviews of the available process safety information (PSI) have been conducted.  Updates to maximum intended inventory (MII) and piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) have been completed.  A comprehensive electronic web-based system utilized for timely access to information has been built, implemented and made available to all personnel involved with operating the process.  

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):
A new PHA team including experienced operating personnel (operations and maintenance), WTG engineers, Process Control personnel, safety representatives, and PSM representatives is planned to conduct a new PHA in October of 2018.  Results and recommendations from these analyses will be actively shared with employees.  Additionally, a process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented for the interactive tracking of PHA action items to closure.

Operating Procedures:
Written operating procedures reference PSI are available.  A written mentorship training program has been developed, implemented, and documented per employee.  A technical review of operating procedures is currently underway while also being formatted into a standard operating procedures format across WTG will be completed.  WTG will also be publishing operating procedures to the company's electronic web-based system.

Management of Change (MOC) and Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR):
Impr

ovements to the MOC procedure and associated checklists are in progress to capture all process related changes.  Requirements for the identification, evaluation, control and authorization of modifications to plant design and operations prior to the implementation to ensure that the risk of new or existing hazards are properly managed is available to all personnel.  Extensive PSSR checklists for applicable disciplines (electrical, instrumentation, procedures, etc.) have been developed and implemented.  These checklists are Appendices to the Company's MOC procedure and are available online from the company's electronic web-based process library. 

Mechanical Integrity (MI):
In addition to the ultrasonic thickness testing program already in practice at Benedum, a complete third-party MI gap assessment has been completed.  This has resulted in the development of revised comprehensive inspection standards and procedures along with a specialized inspection program structured specifically for Benedum.

Incident Investigation:
WTG investigates all PSM incidents.  Throughout the PSM program assessment process, incident investigation procedures are being reviewed and will be updated as necessary.  A mix of WTG personnel will be provided investigation methodology training to further enhance the program and ensure root cause is consistently identified.  A process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented to track action items and incident investigation corrective actions to closure.

Compliance Audits:
To meet compliance with PSM/RMP, WTG conducts compliance audits every three years to verify all PSM/RMP element requirements are being satisfied.  In WTG's general PSM/RMP improvement program initiatives, an updated audit protocol has been established and implemented within WTG.

Emergency Response Program:
The overall emergency response program for Benedum has been coordinated with several local emergency responders that include Reagan County Fire and Emergency, Rankin Volunteer Fire Department, Rankin EMS, and Upton County Sheriff's Office.  The Benedum Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department, Police and Sheriff's office).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  Benedum conducts mock emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations.  The facility will conduct additional emergency drills annually with local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.

Five-Year Accident History:
All incidents that occurred within the previous five years were reviewed to determine whether any are subject to RMP reporting.  One of those incidents, which occurred on September 21, 2015 when a fire started in the CAT Compressor Building, was previously reported and details of this incident are included in Section 6 of the RMP.
